The Center sponsors a variety of cultural, educational, and social programs to address the diverse needs and interests of the LGBTQ community. The Center sponsors workshops and events during theme month celebrations and provides other campus-wide programming to increase campus understanding of LGBTQ issues.   Advocacy :   The Center works with campus and local resources to provide individual support for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer students targeted by acts of bias. Center staff record and report incidents of bias against lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer students. Center staff work with other University units to ensure fast, effective responses to acts of bias.   Training and Consultation:   Center staff offer leadership workshops exploring the challenges, rewards, roles, and skills of effective LGBTQ student leadership.   The Center extends active, ongoing support to student organizations. Center staff provide LGBTQ issues training to campus peer education groups, resident assistants, and various staff units.   The NYU LGBTQ Student Center assists other University offices and individuals in developing programs and services on LGBTQ issues. The Center offers staff and faculty development sessions on various topics affecting the LGBTQ student population.   If you have any questions about the services listed above, please email us at lgbtq.student.center@nyu.edu .              Outspoken Peer Education Program                              Outspoken is a student group devoted to campus peer education, outreach, and advocacy regarding issues of sexual orientation and gender identity and expression. Our efforts aim to create a campus community that understands, welcomes, and supports the identity and experience of every student.   Outspoken is a group of undergraduate students who have completed an intensive training on issues that are current and necessary to the understanding of the concerns in the LGBTQ community. Peer Educator training consists of: a one week training in mid-August, monthly continuing education sessions throughout the Fall and Spring semesters, and a one day Retreat in January. After this training, Outspoken members help to facilitate the various programs described below on a volunteer basis, work together to strengthen Outspoken, and work toward the achievement of its mission.   One of our most popular and well known programs is:     Safe Zone I: NYU LGBTQ 101   This is a campus wide program designed to visibly identify students, staff, and faculty peers who support the LGBTQ population, understand some of the issues facing LGBTQ individuals, and are aware of the various LGBTQ resources. The three hour training session provides a foundation of knowledge needed to be an effective ally to LGBTQ students and those questioning their sexuality. Campus wide trainings are offered twice a semester, but training sessions can be arranged for other groups by request. For more information about Safe Zone trainings, check out our Safe Zone page. Also, be on the lookout for Safe Zone II workshops--entire workshops designed for those that have completed a Safe Zone training and are interested in gainining a deeper understanding of issues and topics within the LGBTQ community. These workshops and programs are offered periodically throughout the year.   To Request a SafeZone I: NYU LGBTQ 101 training for STUDENT groups please click here and fill out the request form!   To Request a SafeZone I: NYU LGBTQ 101 training for FACULTY AND STAFF groups please click here and fill out the request form!     To Register for a Safe Zone Training, please click here!             Program Menu                                           Outspoken members facilitate a number of programs for Residence Halls and other offices on campus. We already have some programs planned and ready to go at any time that you need one, and we can always work with you if there is a specific issue that you wish to address or topic you feel would be useful to learn about. All program requests must be made 2-3 weeks prior to the desired date of the program! Also, be on the lookout for Safe Zone II workshops--entire workshops designed for those that have completed a Safe Zone training and are interested in gainining a deeper understanding of issues and topics within the LGBTQ community. These workshops and programs are offered periodically throughout the year.   Guess the Straight Person : Looking for an interactive, stereotype-breaking activity? For this exercise, audience members pose questions to a panel, trying to determine the sexual orientation or gender identity of panel members. Based on how the panel answers the questions while relying on assumptions and stereotypes, the audience members try to identify the heterosexual panel members. What follows is a riveting discussion that destroys stereotypes and challenges assumptions.     Per Request, other programs we offer are:       Gender the Object     Express Yourself     Queer Jeopardy: Gay Politics in the US   Queer Bingo     Customize a Program     please contact Ian Koncagul @ ihk219@nyu.edu for detailed descriptions and information.                                                                                           Angie Gonzalez (Co-Coordinator)                               Angie is a sophomore in the dual-degree program at College of Art and Sciences and the Polytechnic School of Engineering studying electrical engineering and physics. They work at the LGBTQ Student Center as an Office Assistant. They are also a Site Leader for an Alternative Breaks trip with the LGBTQ Student Center and CMEP. Angie plays the saxophone, loves Magnolia cupcakes, and enjoys watching spongebob. Angie is excited to be an OPE because they want to learn how to create safer spaces and educate others on LGBTQ issues in all of them communities, which include sports groups, STEM spaces, and PoC spaces.                                                                Zev Spiegel (Co-Coordinator)                               Zev Spiegel is a sophomore in the College of Arts and Science studying Dramatic Literature with minors in Child and Adolescent Mental Health Studies and Educational Theatre. He hopes to one day work with kids and theater--whatever that may mean. Zev hails from Chicago, IL and has loved the time he's spent at NYU so far. In his free time Zev enjoys singing off key, dancing badly, and making people laugh. He's currently co-leader of T-Party--the club for transgender and gender nonconforming students and their allies--and is super duper excited to get more involved with the LGBTQ Center.                                                                Tommy Collison                               Tommy is a sophomore studying communications and media criticism. Originally from Ireland, Tommy tend to work on projects where technology and activism collide, and he's passionate about equality and sane internet policies.                                                                Cian Compton-Lujin                               Cian is a sophomore in the College of Arts and Science majoring in English. He is originally from Indiana and spends a lot of time thinking and writing about being a Midwest transplant in the big city. In addition to being an OUTspoken Peer Educator, he is a co-leader of T-Party. He also enjoys queer interpretations of mainstream media, video games, and cosplaying.                                                                Cara Cota                               Cara is a rising junior in CAS studying Social and Cultural Analysis with concentrations in American Studies and Gender & Sexuality Studies, and is extremely passionate about social justice and radical activism. Cara grew up around the city, having lived in the West Village, East Village, and Brooklyn as a child. She is not only an Outspoken Peer Educator, but the co-leader of the T-Party Club, as well as a member of Queer Union. When she’s not involved in/reading about social justice, she can be found slow dancing/crying to Sigur Ros or befriending neighborhood dogs (especially pugs).                                                                Melodie Davis                               Melodie is a junior studying Music Business with a minor in Gender and Sexuality Studies. She was born in Palo Alto, California, eventually moving to a suburb of Paris, France. In her free time, Melodie can usually be found writing songs, drinking peach juice or looking up “rat in a bath” on Google Images. This is her first year as an OUTSpoken Peer Educator.                                                                Ishani Dugar                               Ishani is a sophomore majoring in Psychology and double minoring in Genetics and Gender and Sexuality Studies. They grew up in the San Francisco Bay Area in California and is hugely appreciative of finally having decent public transportation. In their free time Ishani enjoys showing people pictures of their horse. This is their first year as an OUTSpoken Peer Educator.                                                                Ian Koncagul                               Ian Koncagul is a senior in the College of Arts and Science with a major in Social and Cultural Analysis and a double minor in Mathematics and French. He hails from the great region of Detroit, Michigan (@SlowsBBQ). As the OUTSpoken Peer Educator Coordinator at the NYU LGBTQ Student Center, he schedules and plans trainings, tablings, and other outreach & education events for NYU’s LGBTQ and ally communities! In addition to his work at the center, Ian is an RA in Palladium (#palladium6floor) and enjoys tea, french cinema, and modern art.                                                                Kirstin Jackson                               Kirstin is a sophomore at Tisch, where she is studying Dramatic Writing. She was born and raised in California's Bay Area but has adjusted to and learned to love the fast paced New York lifestyle. This is Kirstin's first year as an OUTSpoken Peer Educator and she hopes it gives her a chance to educate the world about LGBTQ issues, starting with herself. In her free time, Kirstin enjoys reading, watching films, cooking, baking, and photography.                                                                AJ Jones                               AJ is a sophomore currently studying Film production in Tisch. They're an OUTSpoken Peer Educator at the NYU LGBTQ Student Center. When they are not spending every waking moment in an editing suit or in the animation studio, they like to try to reach their goal of watching every movie on Netflix, spend some quality time with they're friends, or go to Peet's five times a day.                                                                Axel Keating                               Axel is a junior studying the intersections of social justice, art, activism, radical and critical psychology, queer studies, disability, Deaf culture & ASL, and sex education. With that, they hope to become a sex educator and continue on with activist work as a part of Otter Activism. They are passionate about music, DIY patches and bracelet making, zines, peaches, and otters. Axel is in they second year as an OUTSpoken Peer Educator at the NYU LGBTQ Student Center.                                                                Mars Marson                               Mars is a junior in Tisch studying Film & Television with a minor in Gender & Sexuality Studies, and probably has not seen that movie you're talking about. As a returning OPE, newly-appointed Interactive Media Coordinator of the NYU LGBTQ Student Center, and a leader of two clubs at NYU, Mars does not have time to breathe.                                                                Claire Mahany                               Claire is a west coast expatriate who traded NorCal’s perfect climate and abundant avocados for the excitement and vitality of New York. She is currently a junior in Steinhardt’s Media, Culture, and Communication program, with a minor in Gender and Sexuality Studies. In her free time she likes to comb NYC for San Francisco equivalent burritos and dote on her adorable cat son Apollo with whom she shares a pillow. Claire is a returning OPE, and was a member of the First Year Queers and Allies program.                                                                Piper McCain                               Piper is a senior at the Polytechnic School of Engineering studying Biomolecular Science/Biotechnology. In addition to being an OUTSpoken Peer Educator, Piper is also the president of STEMINIST, a student-run organization centered around introducing intersectional feminist activism to STEM fields. Having moved far from home in Texas, Piper now resides in Brooklyn and in they spare time enjoys tinkering with recipes in the kitchen and daydreaming about cats.                                                                Ivy McCall                               Ivy is a senior studying Global Liberal Studies with a concentration in Histories, Philosophies, and Worldviews. She hails from the Shenandoah Valley, but was eager to trade in mountains for skyscrapers as soon as she could. She has been passionate about LGBTQ issues since she was in high school and is glad to have this opportunity to educate her peers on issues that directly impact her life.                                                                Corynne Peters                               Corynne is a junior in Tisch and the College of Arts and Sciences, working toward a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drama with a concentration in Music Theatre (in the New Studio on Broadway) and a Bachelor of Arts in Social and Cultural Analysis with concentrations in American Studies and Gender and Sexuality respectively. From Northwest Philadelphia, born and raised, post-all girls Catholic college preparatory school, Corynne now spends her time outspokenly peer-educating people, coordinating QUENCH discussions at the Center, facilitating the Center’s Reading Rainbow book club and Fluidity, craving bacon, and singing and dancing and stuff.                                                                Kira Prentice                               Kira is a junior in the College of Arts and Sciences and a first-year OPE. She works as a graphic designer at the NYU LGBTQ Student Center and is looking forward to creating visually striking and creative materials with an intersectional message as an OPE.                                                                Emily Roche                               Emily is a senior in the College of Arts and Sciences pursuing a combined B.A. and M.A. degree in Russian, with triple minors in History, English, and Classics. This year, she plans on writing her senior thesis on the psychology of urban combat and activism in the Warsaw Uprising of 1944. When she isn't weeping quietly over Russian grammatical patterns, Emily enjoys swing dancing, playing the accordion, and staring at the dogs in Washington Square Park. Although this is her first semester as an OPE, she has a year of previous experience volunteering at Bluestockings Bookstore, Cafe, and Activist Center and is excited to get more involved with the LGBTQ community at NYU.                                                                Shaquille Romblay                               Hello!! My name is Shaquille I'm a Brooklyn boy! I'm outgoing, opinionated, and a bit over the top. My goal in life is to have my own talk show so I can continue to be outspoken about various lgbtqia issues. Hopefully one day you will all see me on the small screen!                                                                Lex Santana                               Lex is a Sophmore at the School of Continuing and Professional Studies studying Psychology. They are originally from London and since moving here have developed a thorough appreciation for New York City. In their spare time they can be found running their social justice, gender, sexuality and feminism blog, writing poetry or attached to a Polaroid camera.                                                                Alejandrx Shelley                               Alejandrx is a sophomore at the College of Arts and Sciences majoring in sociology. Born and raised in Latin America, they are particularly interested in Latino gender and sexuality performances, especially in comparison to those in the United States. In their spare time Alejandrx can often be found playing Pokemon, talking about Pokemon, accessorizing, or thinking about Pokemon.                                                                Elana Blank                               Elana is a senior at Gallatin, where she is studying the destigmatization of queerness, sexuality and mental illness, and pursuing a Social Work minor. Originally from Westchester County, Elana completed three semesters at NYU before taking some time off and moving to Vermont, where she interned at an LGBTQ community center and was shocked to discover that she actually likes nature (kind of). Now that she's back in New York, Elana can be found at the Center or in her bed eating Nutella and watching Bob's Burgers.                                                                Robert Taylor                               Robert is a sophomore in the College of Arts and Science studying History and Gender & Sexuality Studies on the Pre-Law track. Hoping to blend his studies together, he takes delight in one day knowing that he will be able to fend for the rights of the oppressed. As a person of Caribbean decent, he plans to use the skills acquired as an OUTSpoken Peer Educator to bring light to LGBTQ issues within his community. On any given day, one will find him doing one of three things: (1) crocheting a baby blanket,(2) being EXtremely loud, or (3) declaring things DELICIOUS with a dash of the RAINBOW!                                                                Mariah Young-Jones                               Mariah is a sophomore at Gallatin studying Human Rights and Music Production. She chose to be an OUTSpoken Peer Educator, because she wants to both better herself, as an ally, and the world at large. When she is not frequenting the LGBTQ Student Center or studying, she can be found trying out new recipes in her kitchen, writing music, or quietly planning world domination.                                         For questions regarding OUTSpoken Peer Education Programs, email the OUTspoken Coordinator, Ian Koncagul.
